text.p: Allstate Corp said Tuesday it continues to build its international insurance business overseas, with an eye to offering coverage in markets such as China and, potentially, Latin America.

"These are what I'd call seeds," Allstate President Edward Liddy told reporters. "In three or five or 10 years, we think they'll grow into something substantive. But they are not going to produce large amounts of revenue or large amounts of income overnight."
Allstate, which had operating income of $1.6 billion and revenue of $24.3 billion in 1996, is setting up a representative office in China.
"In China, we're primarily interested in working with the Chinese government to formulate what the texture and look and feel of an automobile insurance market ought to be," Liddy said.

Allstate is also interested in the Indian insurance market, which is dominated by a state-owned life insurance company that may be privatized. "We would very much like to help them do that," Liddy said.
In Asia, Allstate already has life insurance joint ventures in Korea and Indonesia, and two ventures in Japan to offer life insurance and auto coverage.
Liddy added that Allstate plans to set up an operation in the Philippines, mostly likely in 1998.
In other international markets, Allstate is looking to expand in Italy and Spain. It already offers auto insurance in Germany, selling products directly without agents.
Liddy said Allstate is not active in Latin America, but does see potential in that market in the future.
